title: Workshop on Digital Game-Based Mathematics Concept Learning Design for Early Childhood Education: Focus on Computation, Geometry, and Patterns

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational mathematics education theories (number concepts, geometry, measurement, patterns), experience with digital media, understanding of early childhood cognitive development stages, and basic problem-solving and graph interpretation skills in mathematics
context.additional_context: Enhancing the capability to design math games for young children in smartphone-centric limited-technology environments: optimizing touch-based interfaces (drag-and-drop), internalizing math concepts through gamification elements (scores, levels, rewards), and increasing learning effectiveness via multisensory stimulation (animation/sound effects). It systematically connects calculation, geometry, and pattern domains.

learning_goals: Design three learning objectives for early childhood math games based on the Dick & Carey model: addition/subtraction problem-solving to strengthen basic calculation skills, shape manipulation (rotation/symmetry) for spatial sense development, and pattern recognition to foster logical thinking (discovering regularities).

Applying R&D methodology (requirements analysis–design–development–testing), learners develop one digital game prototype (with formula visualization and graph-based feedback), implement three or more interactive problem-solving scenarios (equation solving, shape classification, pattern completion), and apply a gamification evaluation system (scores/badges/level-ups) to achieve over 80% user satisfaction.

Implement two early childhood learning effectiveness assessment tools via VR simulation: in-game behavioral data analysis (problem-solving time/attempts) and a mathematical concept comprehension rubric (calculation accuracy, shape recognition, pattern prediction).

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
